The primary factor arguing for a 'No' outcome is the established pattern of presidential pardons, including Trump's own in his first term. Trump did not grant his first pardon until August 2017 (his eighth month) and did not exceed the two-person threshold in a single month until well over a year into his presidency. This strong historical base rate suggests a low probability.

However, I have adjusted the probability upwards from this base rate for several reasons. First, a second Trump term is likely to be less constrained by traditional norms. Trump has repeatedly signaled his intention to pardon individuals he sees as political allies, including those involved in the January 6th Capitol riot. There will be significant pressure from his base to act on this quickly. Second, the threshold for a 'Yes' outcome is very low ('more than 2').
